instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used to identify the spatial extent of native habitats and invasive tree species in the Shola Sky Islands of the Western Ghats?
Output: The related study used remote sensing spectrum to identify the spatial extent of native habitats and invasive tree species in the Shola Sky Islands of the Western Ghats.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to identify the spatial extent of native habitats and invasive tree species in the Shola Sky Islands of the Western Ghats?
Output: Hyperspectral, multispectral, and SAR data were used with SVM, Random Forest, and CART classification algorithms to identify the spatial extent of native habitats and invasive tree species in the Shola Sky Islands of the Western Ghats.

instruction: What metric was chosen to identify the spatial extent of native habitats and invasive tree species in the Shola Sky Islands of the Western Ghats and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen to identify the spatial extent of native habitats and invasive tree species in the Shola Sky Islands of the Western Ghats was the support vector machine (SVM) algorithm. This metric achieved a classification accuracy of 98.7%.

instruction: What machine learning classification algorithms were used in the study to assess the accuracy of different remote sensing sensors in identifying the spatial extent of native habitats and invasive tree species in the Shola Sky Islands of the Western Ghats?
Output: The machine learning classification algorithms used in the study to assess the accuracy of different remote sensing sensors were the support vector machine (SVM), classification and regression trees (CART), and random forest (RF) algorithms.

instruction: Can the combination of AVIRIS-NG hyperspectral data and support vector machine algorithm be considered superior to other remote sensing sensors and machine learning algorithms in accurately identifying the spatial extent of native habitats and invasive tree species in the Shola Sky Islands of the Western Ghats?
Output: Yes, according to the study, the combination of AVIRIS-NG hyperspectral data and the support vector machine (SVM) algorithm produced the highest classification accuracy (98.7%) in identifying the spatial extent of native habitats and invasive tree species in the Shola Sky Islands of the Western Ghats. This indicates that this combination can be considered superior to other remote sensing sensors and machine learning algorithms in accurately identifying these habitats and species in the given area.
